purificationRitual.misogi: Purification ritual in river - washing away death pollution
purificationRitual.pollution: Izanagi polluted by contact with death (kegare)

significance: Forbidden gaze motif - Universal mythic theme
Absolute boundary of death - Once dead, cannot truly return
Origin of mortality - Death enters world through this event

historicalContext.parallels: Similar to Orpheus and Eurydice (Greek), Inanna's Descent (Sumerian)
historicalContext.context: Explains origin of death, purification rituals, and three major kami (Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, Susanoo)
historicalContext.sources: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)

narrativeStructure.negotiation: Izanami says she's already eaten food of Yomi, will ask gods if she can return
narrativeStructure.escape: Izanagi flees, blocks entrance to Yomi with massive boulder
narrativeStructure.izanamiDeath: Dies giving birth to Kagutsuchi (fire god) - burns and wounds cause death
narrativeStructure.chase: Izanami, humiliated and enraged, sends hags and warriors to pursue him
narrativeStructure.divorce: They speak final words through boulder - marriage dissolved, death enters world
narrativeStructure.descentToYomi: Izanagi follows her to Yomi (land of the dead)
narrativeStructure.forbiddenGaze: Warns Izanagi not to look at her
narrativeStructure.violation: Izanagi lights torch, sees her rotting corpse covered with maggots and thunder deities

name: Japanese Mythology
description: The Journey of Izanagi to Yomi is one of the foundational myths of Japanese Shinto tradition, recorded in the ancient chronicles Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE). After his beloved wife Izanami dies giving birth to the fire god, Izanagi descends to the underworld realm of Yomi to retrieve her. His journey reveals the absolute boundary between life and death—once crossed, it cannot be undone without terrible consequences.

theologicalAnalysis.deathAsContamination: The concept of kegare (death pollution) parallels biblical purity laws regarding contact with the dead (Numbers 19:11-16), reflecting humanity's instinctive recognition of death's abnormality
theologicalAnalysis.irrecoverableDeath: Izanami's irreversible death after eating Yomi's food points toward the biblical understanding of death as enemy - 'the last enemy to be destroyed' (1 Corinthians 15:26)
theologicalAnalysis.purificationRitual: Izanagi's misogi (purification) after contact with death anticipates Christian baptism as cleansing from the 'old self' and death's power (Romans 6:3-4)
theologicalAnalysis.forbiddenKnowledge: The prohibition against looking back echoes Lot's wife (Genesis 19:26) and the broader biblical theme of transgressing divine commands with tragic consequences

christian.descentToTheDead: Izanagi's descent to Yomi parallels Christ's descent to the dead (1 Peter 3:18-20), though Christ victoriously liberates while Izanagi fails and flees
christian.deathContamination: The concept of kegare reflects the biblical truth that death is an intrusion, a consequence of sin (Romans 5:12), not natural to God's original creation
christian.failedRescue: Like Orpheus, Izanagi's failed rescue of his spouse points to humanity's inability to conquer death through its own power - requiring a divine Savior
christian.purificationBaptism: Izanagi's water purification after contact with death prefigures baptismal theology - 'Wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow' (Psalm 51:7)
christian.lotsWife: The forbidden backward glance and its consequences directly parallel Lot's wife who 'looked back, and she became a pillar of salt' (Genesis 19:26)

comparativeNotes.naturalTheology: The Yomi narrative reveals humanity's natural recognition that death is not the final word - the drive to rescue loved ones from death reflects the imago Dei's intuition of eternal life

patristicCommentary.augustine: Augustine's theology of death as consequence of the Fall applies to understanding why Shinto recognizes death as pollution requiring purification
patristicCommentary.johnOfDamascus: John Damascene's 'Exact Exposition of the Orthodox Faith' on Christ's descent to Hades provides the framework for understanding pagan descent narratives as anticipations
patristicCommentary.gregoryOfNyssa: Gregory's 'Catechetical Oration' on Christ's victory over death illuminates the difference between failed human rescue attempts and divine triumph
patristicCommentary.cyrilOfJerusalem: Cyril's 'Catechetical Lectures' on baptism as death and resurrection connect Izanagi's purification ritual to the Christian sacrament

biblicalParallels: 1 Corinthians 15:26 - The last enemy to be destroyed is death
Romans 5:12 - Sin came into the world through one man, and death through sin
1 Peter 3:18-20 - Christ suffered once for sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, and preached to spirits in prison
Genesis 19:26 - Lot's wife looked back, and she became a pillar of salt
Numbers 19:11-16 - Whoever touches a dead body shall be unclean seven days
Romans 6:3-4 - Baptized into His death; raised to walk in newness of life
Psalm 51:7 - Wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow
Revelation 21:4 - Death shall be no more
typologicalReading: Izanagi's journey to Yomi represents humanity's universal but futile attempt to overcome death through its own efforts. The prohibition against looking, the corruption of the beloved's body, and the necessity of purification all point to deep truths that find their resolution only in Christ. Where Izanagi fails and flees, sealing the realm of the dead with a boulder, Christ descends victoriously and rises again, rolling away the stone. The misogi purification ritual anticipates the Christian sacrament of baptism, where believers are truly cleansed from death's power and united to the Risen Lord. What Shinto recognizes as permanent separation in death, Christianity proclaims as overcome: 'O death, where is your victory? O death, where is your sting?' (1 Corinthians 15:55).

academic: Basil Hall Chamberlain, 'Ko-ji-ki: Records of Ancient Matters' (1882)
Michael Czaja, 'Gods of Myth and Stone: Phallicism in Japanese Folk Religion' (1974)
theological: Hans Urs von Balthasar, 'Mysterium Paschale' (on Holy Saturday and descent)
Jean Danielou, 'The Bible and the Liturgy' (baptismal theology)
Alexander Schmemann, 'Of Water and the Spirit' (on baptism)
patristic: Cyril of Jerusalem, 'Catechetical Lectures' XIX-XXI (on baptism)
Gregory of Nyssa, 'Catechetical Oration' (on death and resurrection)
John of Damascus, 'Exact Exposition of the Orthodox Faith' III.29 (on descent)

definition: The journey of Izanagi to the underworld realm of Yomi to retrieve his deceased wife Izanami, revealing the absolute boundary between life and death and establishing concepts of death pollution and purification rituals.
examples: Izanami dying in childbirth to fire god Kagutsuchi
Izanagi descending to Yomi despite prohibition
The forbidden gaze revealing Izanami's rotting corpse
Izanagi's purification creating major kami (Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, Susanoo)
applications: Psychological work with grief and acceptance

concepts.name: Orpheus And Eurydice   Greek Parallel (Failed Rescue)
Death Archetype   Cross Cultural Death Myths
